title: Alright. Tribunal.
body:
This is why tribunal is cancer. I have a teemo jungle. He AFKs at level 2. I tell my team we can still win 4v5. Since teemo jungle doesn't do anything. He comes back at level 11 and all he does is trash talk and feed. goes 0/5 and AFKs again.

Now this, would all be fine and dandy if the player was punished for AFKing and playing ranked teemo jungle (0 games played on teemo).
However, he proceeds to report me and get players on the other team to report me. While I am playing my ass off, stealing buffs and 1v2ing. What happens? I get suspended. Tribunal system literally punishing me for being trolled and punishing me so I cannot play this video game. 

That's right. You heard it folks. I cannot play a video game because some judgmental prick system you made was abused by 12 year old trolls. If you cannot solve your own problems in the game, you should not be playing the game. If you create a system that rewards passing responsibility of your problems onto others you are simply creating a toxic environment by design.

As I have said many times, if you are interested in actual positive changes to your behaviour system, MSG me privately. This has got to stop. When you create loopholes for children to cry wolf, they will cry wolf every time they see a dog. And then all of the real wolves will simply roam around destroying the game.

replies.body:
Your punishment had nothing to do with the Teemo, it was 100% your own behavior.

I'm actually surprised it wasn't a perma-ban given the content.

Feel free to post your chat logs if you'd like to have an open discussion about it.

So, you guys completely ignore the intentional feeding teemo in this situation? Honestly riot, this is why the system needs to be changed. It doesn't matter what the OP did, but the fact that you didn't punish the intentional feeder in this situation is quite shocking.

1. The Teemo was not intentionally feeding. He had about the same score as everyone else on the team, and was trying to win.
2. Just because someone is penalized for harassment, does not mean the other person will not be punished as well.

If you think someone should be punished, it does not grant you immunity.
I think you guys need to define intentional feeding, cause checking that game out on op.gg proved that he was.

I'm interested to hear what things you think comprise intentional feeding. He has 1 more CS than the enemy jungler. The same number of deaths as about every member of his team. He died in his own jungle twice, and under a turret 3 times defending inhib turret.

Intentional feeding is when someone is not playing the game to win. They are trying to gift kills to the enemy team. Intentional feeding is not having a bad game, or dying.

To be fair, without additional context that Teemo's score _could _ logically indicate that he fed and then proceeded to afk farm rather than try to win the game, especially considering his very low damage to champions. We also know he AFK'd for a good while since he didn't get any XP until about 2.5 minutes in.

Not saying this is an open and shut case, but considering that he was able to get a perfect KDA on several other recent games gives us reason to think that he very well could have intentionally fed. Whether that warrants a reaction from you depends on what other tools you have to confirm this behavior, and what your standard of proof is (neither of which most of us know).

I am in Diamaond 5 and i lost a game on my lv. 25 smurf yesterday with a score on MF with 6 / 12 or sth like that. I had absolut no idea about mf and when to use which skillshot. I was unbelievable hard focused on watching how Q bounces in which scenario. Also i had to go afk 4 minutes because someone knocked at my door. 

I don't feel like Riot should ban me now.

Again, not an open and shut case, and he could be completely innocent. But circumstantial evidence warrants a more thorough investigation using the tools Riot has that we do not possess.

My issue is that Riot Tantram seemed to take the position that it was a foregone conclusion that this guy only had a bad game, presumably without any deeper investigation than what op.gg could provide.

The philosophy of taking actions out of context is so flawed in terms of punishment.

If you take someone killing someone in self defense out of context, and only look at their actions, guess what you have. Murder.

You don't give the community any tools to defend themselves from people trolling, feeding, afkibg, leaving the game because they played 5 minutes before their bed time, you leave players with no other means to defend themselves. Basic animal instinct when cornered is to fight back by any means necessary.

Not only do you not give them any means to defend themselves, you punish them for basic instincts.

This is why the game isn't getting better. Your philosophy is all wrong. Your trying to kill the mosquitoes in your house by wildly swinging a fly swatter and you don't care what you hit. In the process you've failed to realize you left the door open and the mosquitoes are still coming in.

You want to stop toxicity do something to stop 4v5's and trolls

Lmfao at everyone here who has bought into riots PR line. Their current coirse of action isnt going to fix anything, as long as people can troll and afk without any means of the llayers in that game being able to defend themselves, and they lose games because people lose mmr and lp in 4v5s this community will be toxic.

Its never going to away because riot refuses to address it at the root problem.

And all of you attacking me for pointing out are as much to blame for defending riot's laziness. So in a way you are the root problem of the toxicity of league, so stop your white knighting. You're not fooling me

That comparison is massively flawed. A situation where your life is legitimately in danger and the only way to save yourself might be to hurt/kill whoever is after you, versus an indirect interaction where the worst that happens is somebody ruins one game for you...

If somebody else's chat is setting you off to where you're saying things that get you punished in chat yourself, guess what: you could have avoided the situation entirely by muting the other person on the first sign they were going to cause you problems.

That said, I do agree with you that incentive to be good in the first place is an important addition to a system that disciplines bad behavior, in order to have a good, complete system in place.

It doesn't matter what the implications are in terms of severity when compared to each other.

You need to look at the possible outcomes for each situation, for league the best case is a win, the worst case is a loss. In both cases I'm talking about the worst possible outcome of a situation.

I use that example because it truely showcases the logic at hand. The situation never excuses deeply flawed philosophy.

Also, realize that self-defense in League is actually okay, as long as it's truly self-defense and NOT a counter-attack. This is where most people get tripped up. The people claiming to be banned for self-defense are always actually getting caught up because they were counter-attacking.

Self defense could be as simple as using the mute button, like I said before. You can also ask people to stop. If they're attacking a decision you made, you can explain yourself and why you made a decision they don't agree with. 

Fact is, in League (or any video game, really), there is NEVER a valid excuse for berating or harassing teammates.
There is no self defense for a 4v5 or an intentional troll. You just proved my point, I can mute someone who's trying to lose the game on purpose. It won't stop them

What does that have to do with defending yourself in chat? What, specifically, does attacking the troll in chat accomplish? If you're driving 15 over the speed limit but the guy in front of you is going 17 over, are you still breaking the law?

Great point. Apart from the fact that the difference between trolling and flaming isnt 2mph over the speed limit. 

Its more like going 30 over as opposed to 15. If you do both in front of a cop, hes going to grab the one doing 30, not the one doing 15.


Riot however grabs the one doing 15 and lets the one doing 30 go

The speed difference is irrelevant. Which driver is breaking the law? Both. Which players are breaking the rules? Both.

Remember, League is using an automated system to catch these people, so it doesn't work like a single patrol car needing to choose which of the two speeders to catch. The automated system is capable of catching both of them.

Your last statement really brings up the issue in your arguments. You assume the other guy gets away, when there's really no way to know one way or another what happened to the other player. But people are certainly getting punishments for trolling in games (there's even an automated system running now for intentional feeding). 

And a lot of things could explain a difference in punishment vs. not, or a difference in punishment level received. Perhaps the other player was having a one-off game and doesn't behave like that consistently. The system has built-in forgiveness for that (it's targeting players who exhibit patterns of problematic behavior, not one-time offenders). Or maybe they just started doing it regularly but haven't quite hit the point of being punished yet. Or maybe they're between punishments, and that continued behavior is just going to be one more instance leading to further punishments. Or maybe they DID get punished shortly after that game, but it was just a chat restriction, so you wouldn't see a sudden break in games in their match history, like you would with a 2-week suspension or permaban.

The speed difference is completely relavent.

Otherwise your trying to say intentionally feeding is equal to calling someone bad.

Lmfao.

15 over is speeding. 30 over is reckless driving and you can be charged with a misdemeanor for it
Intentional feeding and harassment both are against the rules of League, and both carry the same sorts of punishments if you're found to do them regularly.

Except for one you have ample ways to defend yourself from it. The other you dont.

By not having a fragile ego or using the mute function your game wint be ruined by someone harassing you.

If someone's intentionally feeding theres absolutely nothing i can do to stop then from ruining my gane experience, and im actially held hostage until the 20 minute mark
You're right. There's no recourse aside from reporting the player after the game in these cases. But this point is also very far from your original comment and the start of this conversation.

They aren't just grabbing the people going 15 and letting the people going 30 go. It is more like there are some people driving cars that outrun the police cars(trolls). So to catch them they need to make a coordinated effort that takes more resources per person to catch. But people driving 15 miles over the speed limit are both easily catchable and greatly outnumber those with cars that can outrun the police. So while the threat of each individual going way over the speed limit outweighs the threat of an individual going 15 over, the total threat of all the people going 15 over is greater than the total of all the people who are out running the police.

It is focusing resources where they are most effective. Increasing the net enjoyment of players globally by the largest amount.

They cant catch them so they focus on those commiting lesser crines? Thats my point. They have a fucked up philosophy and if they cared about the community theyd devote more effort to fixing the worse.

But they dont, they only care how the stats reflect their job

Catching trolls is and will probably always be problematic. A lot of it consists of just doing things that are normally fine at inappropriate times. They are also things that people can do on accident, things people could think were the correct choice(even if they were wrong). Ect. Plausible deniability exists. Determining if someone is trolling is mostly judging someone's intentions, not actions. Which is not always possible to accurately do. If you have a better method of doing that then I would love to hear it and I am sure riot would too. I can only think of 2 things that will make a significant improvement to catching these kinds of trolls, inventing a way to read people's minds and increasing the a=mount of innocent people you are willing to have get punished for it.

But yes, you deal with the problem that you can most effectively handle. If you have 1 million dollars to deal with all behavior problems. If that 1 million could catch 1000 trolls or 10,000 toxic players. What would you choose? I am sure some people would choose the 1000 trolls but no thanks. If I look back on my thousands of games and could remove the like 5 trolls I have seen or the 100s of ragers it's the ragers hands down. If riot waved a magic wand and made every single troll magically disappear very little about my league experience would change.

It is just your opinion that trolls are a worse problem. I would agree that 1 troll is worse than 1 toxic chatter. But in my experience, toxic people are exceedingly rare. I'll probably play at least 1000 games this year and I will probably see 1 or 0 trolls in that time and probably at least 100 people who are toxic in chat.
Id taje the 1000 trolls out because if those 1000 trolls stay in the game they'll create 4 toxic players per gameand in 3 games you already have more than 10000 toxic players. Its simple math really

The math is simple because it is made up. Some people definitely get set off by trolls and it causes them to behave poorly as well, but 3 per game? That is just completely made up. Those 10,000 toxic players are setting people off the same way trolls are anyway, maybe not quite to the same frequency but it happens. 

The other issue is that people's response to trolls is feeding the trolls. It is what they want, it is why many of the do what they do. Raging at them is just tossing them a treat for trolling. If you give a puppy a treat every time he shits on the carpet, guess where it's going to shit most of the time?
So you have a source for it then?

Self-defense requires the response to be appropriate. In a physical situation, there is no telling how far it might escalate. In league there is a limit to what someone can do and it isn't much. Thus striking back is not considered an appropriate response. If someone is physically attacking you then striking back has a reasonable chance of stopping the situation. If someone is trying to lose the game on purpose they obviously don't care that you think they shouldn't. That teemo wasn't AFK in the bush because a random guy never berated him for it. Given that he was trying to get the other team to report you I would say that rage is EXACTLY what he wanted. And giving it to him is just tossing him a little treat for his efforts. He then goes on knowing that what he does works.

It isn't wildly swinging a fly swatter around. It is buying a fly swatter mostly for mosquitos but using it swat every insect you see.

I also find it pretty amusing that in the same post claiming that the system is being abused by people trying to pass off blame you are also trying to pass off blame for your own behavior.

In generating it is wilding swinging a fly swatter around.

A player who is having a bad game, doesn't say anything ignores the flame, I'd generally consider yhat a good example of how one should act in that situation.

Now what if he does all that, then the flamers says "I hope your mom gets cancer and you kill yourself from grief". The good player responds with "you are a fucking piece of shit, shut the fuck up". Both those ayers are considered toxic under riots pholosphy, and both will be treated the same, because there is no context.

How is this a far system, and don't respond with "you don't get banned off of one game".

In after vacuum, is that a fair system?

No its not.

That's the philosophy riot has endorsed, and it flies in the face of lytes philosophy that only 7% of the population is actually toxic, and the rest is neutral often triggered in game.

Yet riot looks actually the every player in a vacuum completely ignoring what lyte told us!

So what gives here?

Did lyte lie? Or does riot not give a shit and they like being able to ban more people because it looks like they're making as difference.

They're not

Both of those players are contributing to the negative situation. The first for instigating it and the second for perpetuating it. That situation is worse than it had to be because the second player joined in. Had that "good player" stayed a good player then the situation likely would have fizzled out. This is something I noticed a TON during the overwatch beta. All the same hypercritical ego driven jabs but almost never went past that. That guy one make a handful of those comments throughout the game but since no one ever responded there was never arguments starting.

That statistic(not sure where 7% came from but w/e the specific number doesn't really matter) doesn't contradict that philosophy being effective. Those are two different types of people, and with the exception of extreme behavior, it is only repeated negative behavior that gets you punished. That first guy is going to be doing it regularly because that is who he is, he's just a guy who flames people. So he gets banned. The second guy, the good one, is just a guy who responds to things. He mostly controls himself but running into guy 1 on the wrong day he loses it. But that is just an occasional thing and he doesn't usually get to an actual punishment. Sure there will be some that do. Some have more things that trigger them, some will just get shit on by luck or fate , or randomness that leads to 5 of the first guy in 2 days so they do end up getting punished sometimes, but they still had a hand in those negative situations.
